INTEROFFICE MEMORANDUM
TO: You, Apparently
FROM: Dale Hardigan, Sole Proprietor & Chief Mourner
DATE: Ongoing
RE: Why This Exists

They walked me out of Consolidated Plastics on a Tuesday in November '93. Gave me a banker's box and eleven minutes to fill it. I took the Swingline, a coffee mug that said "World's Most Adequate Employee," and a photograph of the 1989 company picnic where Margie from Accounts Receivable beat everyone at horseshoes and nobody talked about it the way it deserved to be talked about.

"Bernie would've said this better. Bernie said everything better. Then she left."

Here's the thing nobody warns you about: you can hate a place completely ‚Äî hate the carpet, hate the thermostat wars, hate the annual review where Dennis tells you you're "meeting expectations" like that's a compliment ‚Äî and still miss it so bad your chest hurts when you smell toner.

I hated that cubicle. I hated the fluorescent lights that buzzed at a frequency only dogs and middle managers could hear. I hated the mandatory breakroom aerobics. I hated the fax machine that screamed like something dying every time Accounting sent their monthly reports.

"The fax machine is in the store. It still screams. I find it comforting now."

But it was mine. That whole ugly beige world was mine. And it was the last time anyone looked me in the eye and said "you have a future here" and both of us pretended to believe it.

This isn't commerce. It's a wake. Browse respectfully.

CUBE FARM CONFESSIONS

Anonymous. Confidential. Filed in a drawer nobody opens.

I told everyone the fax machine was broken so I wouldn't have to send the quarterly reports. It wasn't broken. I just couldn't handle the sound it made. Like a modem having a panic attack.

Every Friday, Gary from IT microwaved salmon. The whole floor smelled like a pier at low tide. We filed 14 HR complaints. HR filed them in the shredder. Gary outlasted us all.
